December 7, 1923.
Dear Mrs. Gorgas:
div1.p:
I am returning the MSS, which I have read carefully (and more
than once) with criticisms--or rather data on which criticisms can
be based--on a separate sheet.

I have made no marks on the body of the MSS (save one ( ), in
soft pencil, Page 18: (25)): but have written number (and in a few
places letters or (?C)s in pencil on the margin, to which the remarks
in the accompanying sheets refer.

Although in a few places these suggest a change directly, in
general they simply give data which waswere apparently not in the
author's mind at the time of writing, and possibly not known to him.
The suggesion in such cases is obviously that the author with this
fuller knowledge determine for himself whether a change in the MSS
is advisable and, if so, what it should be. In a number of instances
also a note is made without intention or expectation of a change in the
MSS, e. g. Page 10 (Notes) (37: (b) MSS).

Attention is especially invited to Page 22: (35) & (36)--. I am
sure that the reason why the data in my little work were at once
once
-2-
interpreted by Reed to imply the conveyance of yellow fever by an in-
sect host (metaxeny) would have been understood by few laymen--or phy-
sicians for that matter--from the MSS as it stands. It seems to me
then that a skeleton of Ross' findings and their parallelism with my
own is necessary to make this clear.

Also (Page 21: (32)--) I am inclined to think my old formulation of
my own conclusions gives them as Reed saw them better than anything else
would. That, however, is as Mr. Hendricks thinks best.

It has been extremely pleasant to live over the old Habana days.
Guiteras and myself are, I judge, all of the older men (maybe Tomayo
or Albertini) who are now living. I never saw much of Agramonte who
was then a young man. I saw Havard and Menocal in 1920 in Habana.
